models.name: First Principles Framing
models.definition: Reduce complex problems to foundational truths that cannot be further simplified

models.name: Stakeholder Mapping
models.definition: Identify all parties with interest, influence, or impact in a system or decision

models.name: Identity Stack
models.definition: Recognize that individuals operate from multiple nested identities simultaneously

models.name: Lens Shifting
models.definition: Deliberately adopt different interpretive frameworks to reveal hidden aspects of a situation

models.name: Empathy Mapping
models.definition: Systematically capture what stakeholders see, think, feel, and do in their context

models.name: Point-of-View Anchoring
models.definition: Establish and maintain a consistent reference frame before analysis begins

models.name: Perspective Switching
models.definition: Rotate through multiple viewpoints to identify invariants and blind spots

models.name: Narrative Framing
models.definition: Structure information as causal stories with conflict, choice, and consequence

models.name: Cultural Lens Shifting
models.definition: Adjust communication and interpretation for different cultural contexts and norms

models.name: Context Windowing
models.definition: Define explicit boundaries in time, space, and scope for analysis or action

models.name: Role Perspective-Taking
models.definition: Temporarily inhabit specific roles to understand constraints and priorities

models.name: Temporal Framing
models.definition: Organize understanding across past causes, present states, and future implications

models.name: Spatial Framing
models.definition: Scale perspective from local details to global patterns and back

models.name: Reference Class Framing
models.definition: Select comparable situations to inform judgment and avoid uniqueness bias

models.name: Assumption Surfacing
models.definition: Explicitly identify and document beliefs underlying plans or models

models.name: Identity-Context Reciprocity
models.definition: Recognize how identities shape interpretations and contexts reinforce identities

models.name: Frame Control & Reframing
models.definition: Consciously select or reshape interpretive frames to enable new solutions

models.name: Boundary Object Selection
models.definition: Choose representations that bridge multiple perspectives while remaining meaningful to each

models.name: Sensemaking Canvases
models.definition: Deploy structured templates to systematically capture and organize observations

models.name: Worldview Articulation
models.definition: Make explicit the fundamental beliefs and values that drive interpretation and action

models.name: Subtractive Thinking
models.definition: Improve systems by removing elements rather than adding complexity

models.name: Premortem Analysis
models.definition: Assume failure has occurred and work backward to identify causes

models.name: Problem Reversal
models.definition: Solve the inverse of the stated problem to reveal insights

models.name: Contra-Logic
models.definition: Argue the opposite position to stress-test assumptions and expose weak reasoning

models.name: Negative Space Framing
models.definition: Study what is absent rather than what is present

models.name: Inverse/Proof by Contradiction
models.definition: Assume a claim is false, derive logical impossibility, thus proving the claim true

models.name: Boundary Testing
models.definition: Explore extreme conditions to find system limits and breaking points

models.name: Contrapositive Reasoning
models.definition: Use logical equivalence that if A then B equals if not B then not A

models.name: Backward Induction
models.definition: Begin with desired end state and work backward to determine necessary steps

models.name: Red Teaming
models.definition: Organize adversarial review to find vulnerabilities through simulated attack

models.name: Devil's Advocate Protocol
models.definition: Assign explicit role to argue against group consensus or preferred option

models.name: Failure First Design
models.definition: Begin planning by identifying all possible failure modes and designing to prevent them

models.name: Opportunity Cost Focus
models.definition: Evaluate options by what must be forgone rather than what is gained

models.name: Second-Order Effects (Inverted)
models.definition: Trace negative downstream consequences rather than immediate benefits

models.name: Constraint Reversal
models.definition: Temporarily remove assumed constraints to explore alternative solution space

models.name: Inverse Optimization
models.definition: Maximize worst outcomes to understand system vulnerabilities

models.name: Counterfactual Negation
models.definition: Imagine outcomes if key decision had been reversed

models.name: Kill-Criteria & Stop Rules
models.definition: Define conditions that trigger project termination before launch

models.name: Harm Minimization (Via Negativa)
models.definition: Improve by removing harmful elements rather than adding beneficial ones

models.name: Antigoals & Anti-Patterns Catalog
models.definition: Document failure modes to avoid rather than success patterns to emulate

models.name: Synergy Principle
models.definition: Design combinations where integrated value exceeds sum of parts

models.name: Chunking
models.definition: Group related elements into meaningful units to reduce cognitive load

models.name: Functional Composition
models.definition: Chain pure operations where output of one becomes input of next

models.name: Interdisciplinary Synthesis
models.definition: Merge insights from distinct fields to generate novel solutions

models.name: Emergence
models.definition: Recognize higher-order behavior arising from component interactions beyond individual properties

models.name: Gestalt Integration
models.definition: Perceive and leverage whole patterns rather than isolated components

models.name: Network Effects
models.definition: Exploit increasing value as user base or connections grow

models.name: Layered Abstraction
models.definition: Separate concerns into hierarchical levels with clear interfaces between them

models.name: Interface Contracts
models.definition: Define explicit agreements about data structures and behavior between components

models.name: Pipeline Orchestration
models.definition: Coordinate sequential stages with explicit handoffs and error handling

models.name: Pattern Composition (Tiling)
models.definition: Combine repeating elements to construct complex structures efficiently

models.name: Modular Interoperability
models.definition: Ensure independent components work together through standardized connections

models.name: Cross-Domain Analogy
models.definition: Transfer solution patterns from one domain to solve problems in another

models.name: Platformization
models.definition: Extract common capabilities into reusable infrastructure serving multiple use cases

models.name: Combinatorial Design
models.definition: Systematically explore option combinations to find optimal configurations

models.name: System Integration Testing
models.definition: Verify assembled components work correctly together, not just in isolation

models.name: Orchestration vs Choreography
models.definition: Choose between centralized coordination or distributed peer-to-peer interaction

models.name: Knowledge Graphing
models.definition: Represent information as interconnected entities and relationships rather than isolated documents

models.name: Multi-Modal Integration
models.definition: Synthesize information from different sensory or data modalities

models.name: Holistic Integration
models.definition: Unify disparate elements into coherent, seamless whole where boundaries dissolve

models.name: Root Cause Analysis (5 Whys)
models.definition: Iteratively ask why problems occur until fundamental cause emerges

models.name: Factorization
models.definition: Separate multiplicative components to understand relative contribution of each factor

models.name: Modularization
models.definition: Partition system into self-contained units with minimal interdependencies

models.name: Layered Breakdown
models.definition: Decompose from system to subsystem to component progressively

models.name: Dimensional Reduction
models.definition: Focus on most informative variables while discarding noise or redundancy

models.name: Taxonomy/Classification
models.definition: Organize entities into hierarchical categories based on shared properties

models.name: Pareto Decomposition (80/20)
models.definition: Identify vital few drivers producing most impact versus trivial many

models.name: Work Breakdown Structure
models.definition: Hierarchically divide project into deliverable-oriented components with clear ownership

models.name: Signal Separation
models.definition: Distinguish meaningful patterns from random variation or confounding factors

models.name: Abstraction Laddering
models.definition: Move up and down conceptual hierarchy to find appropriate solution level

models.name: Scope Delimitation
models.definition: Define precise boundaries of what is included versus excluded from consideration

models.name: Constraint Isolation
models.definition: Identify specific limiting factor preventing performance improvement

models.name: Failure Mode Analysis (FMEA)
models.definition: Enumerate potential failure points with severity, likelihood, and detectability ratings

models.name: Variable Control & Isolation
models.definition: Hold factors constant to measure single variable's causal impact

models.name: Decision Tree Expansion
models.definition: Map choices and their consequences as branching paths

models.name: Hypothesis Disaggregation
models.definition: Break compound claim into testable sub-hypotheses

models.name: Orthogonalization
models.definition: Ensure factors vary independently without correlation or interdependence

models.name: Scenario Decomposition
models.definition: Partition future possibilities into discrete, mutually exclusive scenarios

models.name: Critical Path Unwinding
models.definition: Trace longest sequence of dependent tasks determining minimum project duration

models.name: Partition-and-Conquer
models.definition: Divide problem into independent subproblems solvable separately then combined

models.name: Recursive Improvement (Kaizen)
models.definition: Continuously refine process through small, frequent enhancements

models.name: Feedback Loops
models.definition: Create mechanisms where system outputs influence future inputs

models.name: Meta-Learning (Learn-to-Learn)
models.definition: Improve the process of learning itself, not just domain knowledge

models.name: Nested Narratives
models.definition: Structure information as stories within stories for depth and memorability

models.name: Fractal Reasoning
models.definition: Recognize self-similar patterns repeating across different scales

models.name: Recursive Framing
models.definition: Apply mental models to the process of selecting mental models

models.name: Self-Referential Logic
models.definition: Create systems that monitor, measure, or modify themselves

models.name: Bootstrapping
models.definition: Build capability using currently available resources, then use that to build more

models.name: Iterative Prototyping
models.definition: Cycle rapidly through build-test-learn loops with increasing fidelity

models.name: Compounding Cycles
models.definition: Design systems where gains reinforce future gains exponentially

models.name: Calibration Loops
models.definition: Repeatedly check predictions against outcomes to improve forecasting accuracy

models.name: Bayesian Updating in Practice
models.definition: Continuously revise beliefs as new evidence arrives, weighting by reliability

models.name: Gradient Descent Heuristic
models.definition: Iteratively adjust toward improvement, even without perfect knowledge of optimal direction

models.name: Spiral Learning
models.definition: Revisit concepts at increasing depth, building on previous understanding

models.name: Convergence-Divergence Cycling
models.definition: Alternate between expanding possibilities and narrowing to decisions

models.name: Retrospective â†’ Prospective Loop
models.definition: Use systematic reflection on past to inform future planning

models.name: Versioning & Diff
models.definition: Track changes over time and compare versions to understand evolution

models.name: Anti-Catastrophic Forgetting
models.definition: Preserve critical knowledge while adapting to new information

models.name: Auto-Refactor
models.definition: Systematically improve system structure without changing external behavior

models.name: Recursive Governance (Guardrails that Learn)
models.definition: Establish rules that adapt based on their own effectiveness

models.name: Leverage Points
models.definition: Identify intervention points where small changes produce disproportionate effects

models.name: System Boundaries
models.definition: Define what is inside versus outside system scope for analysis or design

models.name: Stocks & Flows
models.definition: Distinguish accumulations from rates of change affecting them

models.name: Requisite Variety
models.definition: Match control system's complexity to system being controlled

models.name: Systems Archetypes
models.definition: Recognize recurring dynamic patterns across different domains

models.name: Feedback Structure Mapping
models.definition: Diagram causal loops showing how variables influence each other

models.name: Path Dependence
models.definition: Acknowledge how early decisions constrain future options through accumulated consequences

models.name: Homeostasis/Dynamic Equilibrium
models.definition: Understand self-regulating mechanisms maintaining stable states despite disturbances

models.name: Phase Transitions & Tipping Points
models.definition: Identify thresholds where gradual changes produce sudden qualitative shifts

models.name: Causal Loop Diagrams
models.definition: Visualize circular cause-effect relationships with reinforcing and balancing dynamics

models.name: Governance Patterns
models.definition: Design decision rights, accountability structures, and coordination mechanisms

models.name: Protocol/Interface Standards
models.definition: Specify rules for interaction enabling coordination without central control

models.name: Incentive Architecture
models.definition: Design reward and penalty structures aligning individual actions with system goals

models.name: Risk & Resilience Engineering
models.definition: Build systems that fail gracefully and recover automatically

models.name: Multi-Scale Alignment
models.definition: Ensure strategy, operations, and execution cohere across organizational levels

models.name: Ecosystem Strategy
models.definition: Position organization within network of partners, competitors, and stakeholders

models.name: Policy Feedbacks
models.definition: Anticipate how rules shape behavior, which creates conditions affecting future rules

models.name: Measurement & Telemetry
models.definition: Instrument systems to capture state, changes, and anomalies for informed response

models.name: Meta-Model Selection
models.definition: Choose appropriate framework or tool for specific problem characteristics

models.name: Systems-of-Systems Coordination
models.definition: Manage interactions between independent systems with emergent behaviors
